summary:
I recently graduated from the University of Amsterdam with a master's degree in analytical chemistry (grade 8.0). My research interest focuses on proteomics, glycomics, analytical characterization of protein therapeutics, and application of proteomics in disease diagnosis and drug discovery. I completed a 9-month research internship at UMC Utrecht, where I developed a single-run, liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry method for the quantification of multiple monoclonal antibodies in human plasma. 

My skills:   
Development and validation of LC-MS/MS-based analytical methods
Mass spectrometry analysis of proteins and peptides
Sample preparation methods for LC-MS/MS analysis of monoclonal antibodies
Protein purification and separation techniques (RPLC, SEC, IEC, AC)
Extraction of proteins from cells and cell membranes
Optical spectroscopy of proteins (UV/Vis, fluorescence)
Fluorescence microscopy

profile_positions.description: The goal of this thesis, "Purification of monoclonal antibodies using affinity chromatography-mass spectrometry", was to illustrate that many new monoclonal antibody (mAb) variants formed during post-translational modifications or other modifications can be detected by optimization of the chromatographic conditions and application of a highly selective and sensitive bioanalytical method, the affinity chromatography-mass spectrometry. Different liquid chromatographic techniques and mass spectrometry are routinely applied to study mAbs variants, but these techniques can resolve only the main antibody variants. The Fc receptor affinity chromatography is a highly selective technique to identify and separate antibody variants with tiny structural differences, which have a high impact on the interaction of mAbs with the Fc receptor. By hyphenation of the FcR affinity chromatography with high-resolution and very sensitive mass spectrometry, several low-abundant and highly similar structural variants can be detected. This method proves an efficient tool to assess antibody variants concerning the effect on antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity.
profile_positions.title: Literature thesis- Department of Bioanalytical chemistry

profile_positions.description: The aim of this thesis research project, "Simultaneous quantification of multiple therapeutic monoclonal antibodies in human plasma with LC-MS/MS", was to develop a single-run, liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) based analytical method that can quantify multiple monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) with different targets in human plasma. The developed analytical method includes a target-independent sample preparation of mAbs from human plasma for the LC_MS/MS analysis. This single-run, multiplex mAb analytical method is highly beneficial in clinical practice by significantly reducing the analysis time and expenses.
profile_positions.title: Master Thesis and Research Internship- Department of Clinical Pharmacy
